title: The gender wage gap shrank by just over a dollar in 20 years
text:
Women earned 87 cents for every dollar men earned in 2018, up from 81 cents on the dollar in 1998, according to a new Statistics Canada report. That works out to women earning $4.13 less than men on an hourly basis in 2018, compared to $5.17 less per hour in 1998. (The Logic)

Talking point: Women are more educated and entering a wider range of jobs than they were 20 years ago, which is helping narrow the pay gap. But many of the factors that drove the gender discrepancy in 1998 are the same ones keeping the gap from closing today: women are still underrepresented in high-paying industries like mining and applied sciences, and they tend to have more precarious work—16 per cent of women work part time compared to 4.8 per cent of men. Complicating matters is that two-thirds of the gap remains “unexplained”—even after controlling for things like occupation, union status and hours of work, women still earn $2.62 less per hour than men.
